prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Resolving high redshift sub-mm sources in the WHDF
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to measure the angular size of 15 sub-mm sources already detected using APEX LABOCA. The observations use ALMA band 7 and the C34-4 configuration to obtain observations with an angular resolution of 0."32.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We wish to observe in the same 850 micron (band 7), that we observed with LABOCA, such that we know the precise source flux and the S/N that we will achieve in our ALMA exposures. We propose to observe with the ALMA extended array in the C34-4 configuration to achieve 0."32 resolution.
The positions for the WHDF EVLA detected sources and the ALESS sources are good to sub-arcsecond accuracy. The seven remaining unidentified WHDF sources have positions good to ~9" from the LABOCA observations (Bielby et al 2011) and so will easily be detected within the ALMA primary beam-width, given our conservative exposure times proposed for the ALMA observations as described next.
Our faintest source has a flux of 3.2 mJy. For an extended source of ~ 5-6 kpc, and our resolution scale of 0."32, this would give a mean flux per resolution element of ~ 0.4 mJy. Using the sensitivity calculator, we find that we can reach a 3$\sigma$ sensitivity of 0.4 mJy per resolution element given a 3 min integration time with the C34-4 configuration (345 GHz observing frequency, 7.5 GHz bandwidth and default water vapour settings). The result is approximately the same for both our fields, with the Dec = -27 deg field giving marginally better results. So should a source prove to show a multiplicity of up to a factor of 10x these observations will still make positive detections of the component contributing sources.
Alternatively, assuming a single point source, our faintest target at 3.2 mJy would have S/N~25.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Resolving high redshift sub-mm sources in ALESS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to measure the angular size of 15 sub-mm sources already detected using APEX LABOCA. The observations use ALMA band 7 and the C34-4 configuration to obtain observations with an angular resolution of 0."32.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We wish to observe in the same 850 micron (band 7), that we observed with LABOCA, such that we know the precise source flux and the S/N that we will achieve in our ALMA exposures. We propose to observe with the ALMA extended array in the C34-4 configuration to achieve 0."32 resolution.
The positions for the WHDF EVLA detected sources and the ALESS sources are good to sub-arcsecond accuracy. The seven remaining unidentified WHDF sources have positions good to ~9" from the LABOCA observations (Bielby et al 2011) and so will easily be detected within the ALMA primary beam-width, given our conservative exposure times proposed for the ALMA observations as described next.
Our faintest source has a flux of 3.2 mJy. For an extended source of ~ 5-6 kpc, and our resolution scale of 0."32, this would give a mean flux per resolution element of ~ 0.4 mJy. Using the sensitivity calculator, we find that we can reach a 3 sigma sensitivity of 0.4 mJy per resolution element given a 3 min integration time with the C34-4 configuration (345 GHz observing frequency, 7.5 GHz bandwidth and default water vapour settings). The result is approximately the same for both our fields, with the Dec = -27 deg field giving marginally better results. So should a source prove to show a multiplicity of up to a factor of 10x these observations will still make positive detections of the component contributing sources.
Alternatively, assuming a single point source, our faintest target at 3.2 mJy would have S/N~25.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to test the hypothesis that bright sub-mm galaxies (SMGs) are powered by obscured AGN. We shall do this by measuring the angular size of fifteen SMGs. Nine of these SMGs are X-ray quiet and form a complete sample from LABOCA observations of the WHDF. The other six SMGs are identified with luminous absorbed X-ray QSOs at z~2, with two coming from the WHDF, supplemented by four from ECDFS ALESS. Our aim is to use exquisite ~0.3arcsec ALMA resolution to determine if either of these SMG classes resolve into galaxy-wide starbursts, hence ruling out an AGN power-source for the dust emission. The six X-ray quasars will also act as a control sample for the other nine SMGs allowing a direct comparison of the resolvability between the two classes. If the SMGs are generally resolved then it would strongly suggest a star-forming origin for the sub-mm background. If the X-ray quiet SMGs are resolved and the X-ray loud are not then it will suggest SMGs comprise two different sub-populations, AGN- and star-formation dominated. This or any other outcome is guaranteed to reveal further the nature of SMGs and also the origin of the sub-mm and X-ray backgrounds.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Cycle 0: A direct test of the AGN contribution to the high redshift Sub-mm population Cycle 1: Resolving AGN and SMGs - A `Rosetta Stone' for the X-ray and Sub-mm backgrounds
